4.88.text:
You could go just about anywhere
on the planet

7.36.text:
and Botticelli's images
would be instantly recognised.

9.80.text:
Far beyond the art world,
his influence can be seen in everything

13.04.text: from pop music to the silver screen,

15.64.text: from street art to high fashion.

19.12.text:
This has to be the most surprising
introduction to an exhibition

22.80.text:
I think I've ever seen,
because you walk into this introductory,

26.52.text:
darkened gallery, and there isn't a single
work by Botticelli in sight —

31.24.text:
not even one by the lowliest member
of his workshop.

34.00.text:
Instead, we've got this film clip
of the first Bond film, Dr No,

38.56.text:
the famous sequence
in which Ursula Andress arises

41.52.text:
from the waves, like the goddess
in Botticelli's Birth Of Venus.

45.68.text:
Juxtaposed with that, twinkling on a wall
in the gloom over there,

52.04.text:
Botticelli isn't like other old masters
such as Leonardo or Michelangelo.

57.00.text:
For more than 300 years,
he was practically forgotten.

60.08.text:
It was only in the 19th century
that his fortunes changed

65.36.text:
Pre-Raphaelite artists such as Dante
Gabriel Rossetti and Edward Burne-Jones,

69.52.text:
as well as art critics like John Ruskin
and Walter Pater,

73.04.text:
started championing
and collecting Botticelli's work.

76.56.text:
Today, he's seen as
one of the greatest artists of all time.

80.84.text: This portrait was owned by Rossetti,

83.64.text:
so it was crucial,
in terms of the rediscovery, the legacy,

87.76.text:
the enduring influence of Botticelli
in the 19th century.

90.04.text:
Not only has it been newly restored,
so the paint looks as sumptuous as ever,

95.44.text: but also, it's a very unusual portrait.

97.60.text: At the time, most portraits of women,

99.64.text:
conventionally, would have shown them
very demure with their eyes downcast.

104.36.text: Here, we have this memorably frank,

107.16.text:
direct, very modern stare,
engaging with the viewer —

111.80.text:
a bit like she's a hostess
chiding us for being late.

116.96.text:
Botticelli knew great success
during his own lifetime.

120.40.text:
At the height of his fame, he ran
a highly productive workshop in Florence

124.28.text:
and was one of the most esteemed artists
in Italy.

127.08.text:
His graceful pictures
of the Virgin and child,

131.16.text:
and life-size mythological paintings
were immensely popular.

134.72.text:
This is emphatically
one of the high points of the exhibition.

139.44.text: It's one of Botticelli's very grand

141.44.text:
mythological paintings
called Pallas And The Centaur.

147.48.text:
All of these particular
Florentine fashions and customs,

151.44.text:
even down to the three rings
you can see on her garments,

154.92.text: an emblem of the Medici family,

157.16.text:
a very powerful family at the time,
Botticelli's patron.

159.72.text:
What you have is this great interplay
between a woman

163.16.text:
quelling feelings of —
I don't know — carnality, lustfulness,

167.44.text:
represented by this bestial Centaur,
in this thoroughly beguiling mix.

174.64.text:
There's extraordinary diversity
in this exhibition,

178.32.text:
with artists from William Morris
to René Magritte to Andy Warhol,

182.72.text:
as well as fashion designers
like Dolce & Gabbana.

185.92.text:
But the show truly belongs, of course,
to Botticelli,

197.16.text:
are unmistakably the work
of a true master.

200.08.text:
There's no question that
this Botticelli Reimagined exhibition,

206.16.text:
is, in terms of its conceit, really quite
bold and original — even ballsy.

210.48.text:
Some people might find
this whole approach infuriating,

214.16.text:
but there'll be lots of people
who also find it invigorating,

220.04.text:
I think that's why
it's worth coming to see for yourself.

222.64.text: Whatever your take on the overall concept,

225.84.text:
within all the tricksiness and the
post-modern qualities of the exhibition,

229.60.text:
there is a really beautiful,
quite classical Botticelli retrospective

233.72.text: which is waiting to leap out.
